One possible reason why Mr. Xi may be reluctant to use force in Hong Kong would be that a bloody suppression will easily go down in history and alienate many Hong Kong people. In the short term this will obviously have no effects on China's rule, but one may easily see that if China's power should wane in the future, memories of recent bloodshed will easily kindle and energize calls of independence and make Hong Kong exceptionally difficult to manage then. Hong Kong is, after all, not exactly like Beijing; the CCP government can kill off as many people in Beijing as they want, and no one will ever call for Beijing to split away from China or to resist Chinese rule. The same cannot be said of Hong Kong.

Also, a brutal crackdown in Hong Kong will certainly affect Taiwanese politics. Now, it's true that Xi probably does not expect Taiwan to consent to being taken over by the mainland any time soon, but cracking down on Hong Kong will likely give political ammunition to the Taiwanese faction opposed to increased economic cooperation with the mainland, which backed the Sunflower movement earlier. No doubt news of bloodshed in Hong Kong will push many Taiwan voters to reject the current government's policy of cooperation with the mainland, a situation which Xi's government might hate to see.

In the end, of course, Xi will have to balance these different considerations; he cannot, however, expect to just send in the tanks and be done with it, as you make it sound like.

This story suggests Xi sees a tradeoff of safety for all of China and something "palatable" to 7 million in Hong Kong and not an embarrassment "especially under the glare of international attention."

Sorry, but that is not a hard call, or even a tradeoff at all, to someone like Xi. Remember Tianamen Square, when tanks ran right over protesters and vast numbers were killed in the main public square under the picture of Mao? That is the reality of this.
